segments.en: Numbered Discourses 3
8. Ānanda
73. With Mahānāma the Sakyan
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā gilānā vuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
segments.en: Now at that time the Buddha had recently recovered from an illness.

segments.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “dīgharattāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi:
segments.en: “For a long time, sir, I have understood your teaching like this:
‘Knowledge is for those with immersion, not those without immersion.’

segments.pli: Samādhi nu kho, bhante, pubbe, pacchā ñāṇaṃ;
segments.en: But, sir, does immersion come first, then knowledge?
Or does knowledge come first, then immersion?”
Then Venerable Ānanda thought,
“The Buddha has recently recovered from an illness,

segments.pli: Ayañca mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ atigambhīraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati.
segments.en: and this Mahānāma asks him a question that’s too deep.

segments.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ ekamantaṃ apanetvā dhammaṃ deseyyan”ti.
segments.en: Why don’t I take him off to one side and teach him the Dhamma?”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ bāhāyaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ apanetvā mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Ānanda took Mahānāma by the arm, led him off to one side, and said to him,

segments.pli: “sekhampi kho, mahānāma, sīlaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā, asekhampi sīlaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā; sekhopi samādhi vutto bhagavatā, asekhopi samādhi vutto bhagavatā; sekhāpi paññā vuttā bhagavatā, asekhāpi paññā vuttā bhagavatā.
segments.en: “Mahānāma, the Buddha has spoken of the ethics, immersion, and wisdom of a trainee; and the ethics, immersion, and wisdom of an adept.
What is the ethics of a trainee?

segments.pli: Idha, mahānāma, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati … pe … samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, with good behavior and supporters. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
This is called the ethics of a trainee.
And what is the immersion of a trainee?

segments.pli: Idha, mahānāma, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi … pe … catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.
This is called the immersion of a trainee.
And what is the wisdom of a trainee?

segments.pli: Idha, mahānāma, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti … pe … ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
segments.en: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
This is called the wisdom of a trainee.

segments.pli: Sa kho so, mahānāma, ariyasāvako evaṃ sīlasampanno evaṃ samādhisampanno evaṃ paññāsampanno āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: Then a noble disciple—accomplished in ethics, immersion, and wisdom—realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, mahānāma, sekhampi sīlaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā, asekhampi sīlaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā; sekhopi samādhi vutto bhagavatā, asekhopi samādhi vutto bhagavatā; sekhāpi paññā vuttā bhagavatā, asekhāpi paññā vuttā bhagavatā”ti.
segments.en: In this way the Buddha has spoken of the ethics, immersion, and wisdom of both a trainee and an adept.”
